3. A copy of the facility's Emergency Business Plan (EBP) has been submitted to the Heath Fire
Department. The plan was last updated in September 2023. Any substantial changes to the plan will be submitted to the Heath Fire Department.

The Behr Process Corporation Distribution Center located at 1201 James Parkway, Heath,
Ohio (Heath DC or facility) is subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention Provision
(CAPP) regulations, also known as the Risk Management Plan or RMP regulations, found at 40
CFR Part 68.

The Heath DC is a warehouse operation where products in consumer packaging, including aerosol cans, are received, stored and ultimately shipped to various retail locations. Aerosol cans are stored within a fully enclosed caged area within a room with self-closing doors. The aerosol can storage area is equipped with racks and an in-rack sprinkler system that provides water at each level of the racks. The storage area has a capacity of approximately 600,000 aerosol cans. The aerosol cans are 13 ounces (oz.) by weight and are stored in boxes of either six, 12 or 24 cans per box. Aerosol cans contain various spray products. Based on information provided by Behr, the products themselves do not contain any RMP toxic or flammable substances; however, the propellants added to the cans include the following RMP-regulated substances: propane, butane, isobutane, and dimethyl ether. Each can may contain up to 60% by weight of a mixture of these flammable substances.

Based on the maximum storage capacity of the aerosol storage cage at the distribution center, the Behr facility exceeds the applicable threshold of 10,000 pounds (lbs) of a flammable regulated substance. Based on the worst case scenario modeled using RMP*Comp, and the accident history of the facility related to the storage of aerosol can products, the facility is subject to the Program Level 1 requirements.

The Behr facility meets the Program Level 1 criterion as follows:
1. The facility has not had a release from the aerosol can storage area in the last five (5) years that reached an off-site receptor.
